subject: Re: [junit] Re: Parameterized test with default value
msgSnippet: kelsyc, Would Cedric s suggestion satisfy your original request?  Thanks, David Saff
messageBody:
kelsyc,

Would Cedric's suggestion satisfy your original request? Thanks,

David Saff

On Fri, Apr 11, 2008 at 12:25 AM, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> FYI, here is how we do it with TestNG, maybe something similar could be
> considered for inclusion in JUnit?
>
> @Parameters("port-number")
> @Test
> public void connect(@Optional(1024) int port) { ... }
>
> If "port-number" is supplied in the XML file, it's used, otherwise the test
> method will be passed 1024.
>
> --
> Cédric
>
>
> On Thu, Apr 10, 2008 at 3:37 PM, toalexsmail <toalexsmail@...> wrote:
>
>> I thought again and I found some other solutions.
>>
>>
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "kelvsyc"
>> <kelvsyc@...> wrote:
>> >
>> > I've just gotten into parameterized testing and customized JUnit4
>> > Runners, but I have a few questions:
>> >
>> > How do I go about making a parameterized test for which a single
>> > default parameter value is provided if a list of parameter values is
>> > not given? (It appears to me that you may need to have a custom
>> > runner that's similar to Parameterized)
>> >
>> > Furthermore, suppose I have a subclass of this test, which defines a
>> > second parameter, which, unlike the first, is a required parameter
>> > (ie. I can choose to have my list of parameters as either two values
>> > or a single, which would assume the usage of a default value). How
>> > would I go about doing that? (Would I need to use a different runner?)
>> >
>> > How would I generalize this to any number of parameters (required and
>> > optional)?
>> As I stated in my previous answer in Java the only way to supply
>> default parameters to function (and to constructor as I explained) is
>> to overload it when one constructor call another. But what you could
>> do is to move this calculation of default values from the only
>> constructor to @Parametrized static method. Because you can't declare
>> more than one constructor you should define helper class for this purpose.
>> For example, you want to use 2 parameters one is boolean with default
>> value false and second is required.
>>
>> @RunWith(Parameterized.class)
>> public class YourTest {
>> @Parameters
>> public static Collection<?> testFindLastOrder(){
>> return Arrays.<Object[]>asList(new Object[][]{
>> YourTestHelper helper = new YourTestHelper();
>> {helper.getDefaultFlagValue(), OrderType.SIGN_UP, 1}, // 0
>> {helper.getDefaultFlagValue(), OrderType.SIGN_UP, 15}, // 1
>> {true, -7}, // 1
>>
>> };
>> private boolean flag;
>> private int i;
>>
>> public YourTest(boolean flag, int i){
>> this.flag = flag;
>> this.i = i;
>> }
>> ...
>> }
>>
>> public class YourTestHelper {
>> public boolean getDefaultFlagValue(){
>> return false;
>> }
>> }
>>
>> You can optimize this code, but the idea is clear. If you subclass
>> YourTest class and want to change parameters that are passed to the
>> test class, you should simply define @Parameters method in your
>> subclass. You will use, perhaps, different helper class, which in is
>> case, perhaps subclasses YourTestHelper.
>>
>> > Finally, what if I wanted my parameterized tests to be named via some
>> > naming function (instead of serially numbered like Parameterized)?
>> >
>> You can consider to use Theories instead of Parameterized. Their you
>> have support for this. Note, that Theories run all permutations of
>> your parametrizes, so it can be not exactly what you want. I have no
>> experience by using this though, so I can't help you more.
>>
>>
>>
